title: This is something that really should be talked about
body:
ok so. seen this pop up on Reddit and there has been some talk about it.
not everyone goes to Reddit and I also noticed its not on the boards so I thought I would post, and see what peoples thoughts were on the topic.
I'm going to quote what I said on Reddit. 


> All memes, and trash talk aside
> 4k for that is bullshit. We have no funding in OCE.
> The amount of money to even do these bootcamps is huge for OCE orgs. and (correct me if I'm wrong) get practically no help from RIOT.
> OCE gets fuck all in terms of competitive drive and sources of development. yet punished when they are proactive and seek it.
> Those bootcamps bring so much back to the OCE Region. the knowledge, habits and mentality they learn actually trickles down the ladder.
> 

While I understand account sharing isn't a good thing to do. I feel like we just don't have recourses in OCE.
When you compare us to other wildcard regions we have close to no support or ability to increase our skillcap.

Some wildcard teams play on EUW and can scrim pro and challenger teams. _(likkrit and other star players from multiple regions have stated this and the fact OCE is STUCK! in AMA's)_
Others scrim on NA and have options there. 
the rest can scrim on china

that leaves japan, India and OCE.

japan server I'm told is very competitive and driven. games are very serious past gold 2.

India isn't really started yet, however it will have access to Chinese teams which will allow Indian teams to catch up to other regions quite quickly

**OCE has nothing. 
We have no international events in our region, we don't have teams visit our region. and we have a very small player base.**

Do I believe the fine is fair? **No I don't.**
Do I believe the bans are fair? **Yes I do, but only just.**



Edit: Sorry about the spelling and grammer. I'm doing this from a phone and i'm very tired.

replies.body:
Hi there Mr/Mrs Salad!

It's not appropriate to discuss the specifics of an investigation (current or closed) so I won't go into that, however I'd like to share some of our philosophies which might help you understand why we've made the decisions we have.

One of our long term strategies is to support our teams in their journey towards becoming powerhouses. I believe a strong league needs strong teams and vice versa. It's critical for the success of esports in Oceania that our teams continue to evolve; become businesses, grow fan bases, etc. Look at your favourite NRL/AFL team - they create content, they field professional teams, they have fans, they give back to the community and they operate a business. That's where we want our esports teams to get to. There is a ways to go, but we're making progress. There will be growing pains, but this is part of growth. We believe to achieve this we need to focus on three pillars:

1. Financial support
2. Mentorship + non financial support
3. Standards of operations

The financial support we are offering teams this year is around double what it was last year. All 8 teams are now in gaming houses in Sydney, players earn more than last year and they compete in our studio. Studio games allow teams to create content which is appealing to brand partners who also are injecting revenues, plus it's obviously great for fans. We've also introduced a number of investor opportunities to teams, some of which have now been realised. 

We are also assisting teams in growth where possible as requested. We share data they can use to pitch to sponsors, provide feedback on materials they send to sponsors and give tours of our facilities to prospective partners. 

The third is standard of operations. As esports evolves, it requires everyone to evolve with it. Contracts, official communications and deadlines are all important. If we want to provide teams with the framework to grow, we need to expect and enforce certain operational standards. 

Hopefully this gives you an idea of what we've made the decision we have in this case. You're clearly passionate about the OPL which is awesome, so please, continue to support your OPL team.

Cheers

Riot Stupendous
aka Daniel Ringland

I like that riot is paying attention to these issues however posting a lengthy version of "yeah nah we do heaps aye" doesn't get to the root of the issue nor does it acknowledge that the riot support of the OCE region is sub par. if we cant easily scrim against other regions or travel internationally to compete why would e sports clubs continue to invest in the region. i believe that pushing this issue aside and refusing to take responsibility is only going to further hurt a region that is widely called a joke among all the other regions. i would hope that this spurs a few people into action in working to ensure that a club has more support both domestically and more importantly while traveling, or at least put us all out of our misery and admit that OCE will never be a focus of "real" change.

Also the argument of  "we put in a lot to the pro scene this year" is a bit redundant considering it hasn't been to spur OCE ahead but to make it almost but not quite on par with all other regions. Dont make the mistake of thinking the fans of OPL are going to be eternally grateful that you finally manage to take us to a point that korea and even NA were at 4 years ago.

Hey Rajijin Bokun

Completely understand the sentiment but just to be really clear we do actively support Pro teams, both locally and internationally in terms of logistics, as well as financially.

To avoid all doubt and not give you another 'yeah nah' - We provide accounts to professional players in any region they wish to visit and make introductions to local teams in order to help facilitate scrims. When it comes to international competition, we support the whole process - providing (and paying for) visas, flights, accommodation etc for the competing team. 

To your point about not being able to easily scrim against other regions - outside of these boot camps and international competitions, there isn't a way for our Pro teams to scrim with other regions without having huge ping issues, thus they do not bother. This is something that is unfortunately just due to the nature of our location and doesn't have any easy solution other than encouraging teams to boot camp internationally.

For the point about us putting a lot into the pro scene this year, although we haven't publicly disclosed exactly what we pay - all the teams are living in gaming houses (up to 7 bedrooms) that are heavily funded by Riot among lots of other things. I agree with you that we are still years behind NA/Korea, but we are definitely working as hard as we can on bridging that gap.

I think it is also important to note that there is more that we invest into the scene than purely financial investment - we are working really hard on establishing good long term partners who provide value to our players, spending a lot of time and effort in establishing a solid foundation for OCE Esports - from a behaviour expectation perspective to centralised revenue generation for teams, to more Live playing experience for players etc

I really hope this provides some more concrete answers and examples of how we definitely are working on bridging the gap between OCE and the other regions - we want our oceanic fans to be proud of their region, teams and players and unfortunately there are naturally some growing pains associated with getting there!

I came looking here to see if this ^ was posted!
I have posted it. I made a new topic. should be in the new section.

I think they got off lightly myself, account sharing is a serious offence and not something the top players from our region should ever be a part of. People need to realize that these people are role models for the whole community (whether they like it or not) and need to hold themselves to a higher standard to encourage fair play, not be part of things like this.

It is a failure of management if the team didn't have the resources required for the trip. And and even bigger failure to allow the players to break the rules.

I think the punishment is very light, if they found themselves in the same situation again would they still be tempted? Probably. If the punishment was a disqualification from the current split altogether and automatic demotion to the Challenger Series(very harsh, yes) would they risk it again with that much at stake, probably not.

Hey Guys, it's really good to see that you guys care about the region and our players ability to train internationally etc, as we do. I don't want to let this thread go by without having a Riot comment on it, so I'm starting with this one. We will provide some more context around what we do provide teams and pro players to dispel some of the myths that we don't help, and that there is no funding. (This isn't that response)

Fruitsalad definitely raises some strong points about our region having it very tough when it comes to practicing on other servers though, an unfortunate reality based on our location and the ping to other servers :(

It's just a showing of riot being inept when it comes to what they do.

What are they supposed to do?

Of course they used accounts they didn't own, makes sense to me, not like riot would ever help them either.
